channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-12346] Scan's default auths behavior under Visibility labels
item.description:
In Visibility Labels security, a set of labels (auths) are administered and associated with a user.
A user can normally only see cell data during scan that are part of the user's label set (auths).
Scan uses setAuthorizations to indicates its wants to use the auths to access the cells.
Similarly in the shell:


scan 'table1', AUTHORIZATIONS => ['private']

But it is a surprise to find that setAuthorizations seems to be 'mandatory' in the default visibility label security setting. Every scan needs to setAuthorizations before the scan can get any cells even the cells are under the labels the request user is part of.

The following steps will illustrate the issue:

Run as superuser.


1. create a visibility label called 'private'

2. create 'table1'

3. put into 'table1' data and label the data as 'private'

4. set_auths 'user1', 'private'

5. grant 'user1', 'RW', 'table1'

Run as 'user1':


1. scan 'table1'

This show no cells.

2. scan 'table1', scan 'table1', AUTHORIZATIONS => ['private']

This will show all the data.

I am not sure if this is expected by design or a bug.
But a more reasonable, more client application backward compatible, and less surprising default behavior should probably look like this:

A scan's default auths, if its Authorizations attributes is not set explicitly, should be all the auths the request user is administered and allowed on the server.

If scan.setAuthorizations is used, then the server further filter the auths during scan: use the input auths minus what is not in user's label set on the server.
item.summary: Scan's default auths behavior under Visibility labels

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
In this accumulo doc:

http://accumulo.apache.org/1.6/examples/visibility.html

"The default authorizations for a scan are the user's entire set of authorizations."
Attached a patch If everyone agrees with proposed change to the default auths behavior.

The default scan label generator has the behavior you describe. If you don't ask for any authorizations you don't get any. There is another label generator that will do what you want but will force the user's assigned set. Label generators are stackable. It could make sense to change all of this around a bit to have the default configuration start with the generator that adds labels assigned to the user in the labels table, with another generator stacked on top that adds auths passed in on a Scan attribute. This would be more flexible then the result after the proposed patch is applied.

Also, I don't believe we should or even can aim to be transparently like Accumulo. The labels feature should be most useful and relevant for HBase users building HBase applications. Maybe the proposal here by consensus meets that test, but that would be independent of what any Accumulo documentation says (or doesn't). We did aim for some familiarity in the design of the API and shell commands but I'm not sure in retrospect that's more harmful (because we aren't going to get Accumulo exact semantics with a tag based implementation) than helpful.

HI, Andrew Purtell

Thanks for the comment.

I agree that we should not and can not follow Accumulo blindly.
On the contrary, if you think about it, it is probably more ok for Accumulo to force their scanner applications to setAuthorizations(), since Accumulo has had it since the beginning. At least no backward compatible issue.

For us, ask users to re-write their read applications to order to use visibility labels is less desirable and not practical.
While doing enablement and advocacy work for this feature, the feedbacks I got include 'confusion'.

Stacking multiple label generators will do the trick. But it is probably more suitable for advanced users and will complicate things.
I think a reasonable and practical out-of-box experience is more important.

We have EnforcingScanLabelGenerator which will always give back the user's auth labels and ignore whatever passed in Scan Authorizations. Even if the scan passes a subset of user's auth labels, that is ignored and will assign all user auths. And this is not the default impl
DefaultScanLabelGenerator when passing no Authorizations in Scan, give back no results.
I am more inclined towards doing what this jira proposes. That looks easy for use. We can have stack of ScanLabelGenerator and achieve what user wants. But a default behaving the said would be more user friendly IMO.
I was also thinking on this some time back and make things easier. What do you say Andy?
Attached v2 with a new test case.

This message is automatically generated.

Hi, Andrew Purtell
Do you have additional comment or other concern?
Looking for a nod from you.
Does this mean we have EnforcingScanLabelGenerator and DefaultScanLabelGenerator both doing the same work?

Does this mean we have EnforcingScanLabelGenerator and DefaultScanLabelGenerator both doing the same work?

No. EnforcingScanLabelGenerator dont care what Auths passed in Scan at all. (if some is there or none) It always enforces all labels the user is auth for.
DefaultScanLabelGenerator even after with this patch honor the Authroizations in Scan (if any). It can be a subset of the user auths. If none is passed then we default back to all. (Like Accumulo behaves)
Anoop Sam John explained well. Thanks, guys.

As I said above now that we can stack SLGs , we could have at the bottom, one SLG that copies the auths from the scan, and then layered on top a SLG that adds the defined set for the user from the labels table, this stacked configuration could then become the default. This could make it easier to (re)combine these behaviors with other simple SLGs in the future. Rather than pack everything into DefaultSLG. However I have no strong opinion.

Hi, Andrew Purtell

As long as we agree on the external default behavior, how we do it is internal implementation. I am fine with either approach: single SLG or stacked SLGs.
Here is what we want to expose as the default behavior that we seem to agree on:
1. If there is no Auths in the scan, we will get the defined set for the user from the labels table.
2. If there is Auths in the scan, we will examine the passed in Auths and drop the ones that the user is not entitled to. Then use the resulting label set.

I was thinking about stacked approach since you first mentioned it.
It does not seem to be an easy thing to do it elegantly if we think closely given the current stacking design.

A SLG to copies the auths from the scan is only a 'pass thru' SLG. It does not seem to help to use it in a stack.
The design I can come up to accomplish the above default behavior is the following:
1. Something similar to EnforcingScanLabelGenerator as the first SLG. But we need to change it a little:
a. Get the defined set for the user from the labels table ONLY IF the auths in the scan is null.
b. Otherwise does nothing, pass on the auths in the scan to the next SLG.
2. The current DefaultScanLabelGenerator (without the patch) as the second SLG. This SLG will filter/drop labels from the passed in Auths as needed.

Maybe I didn't completely understand what you meant in the above comment regarding the two SLGs
Please advise. Thanks.

1. Something similar to EnforcingScanLabelGenerator as the first SLG. But we need to change it a little:
a. Get the defined set for the user from the labels table ONLY IF the auths in the scan is null.
b. Otherwise does nothing, pass on the auths in the scan to the next SLG.
2. The current DefaultScanLabelGenerator (without the patch) as the second SLG. This SLG will filter/drop labels from the passed in Auths as needed.

Yes.

And:

  • We could rename 'DefaultScanLabelGenerator' to something more suitable.
  • The default SLG configuration becomes this combined stack.

Sounds good.
I will have a patch and test it out.
Thanks!

Attached v3 patch that does the following:

Rename DefaultScanLabelGenerator.java to GlobalFilterScanLabelGenerator.java

In VisibilityUtils, if no SLG is specified in conf, add two SLGs to be used by default
1. EnforcingScanLabelGenerator
2. GlobalFilterScanLabelGenerator

Slight change to EnforcingScanLabelGenerator

New test: TestDefaultScanLabelGeneratorStack

I've tested the patch to make sure it follows the comments above.

This message is automatically generated.
Patch looks good to me. Will the order of the SLG have a different behaviour? Just asking.

Hi, ramkrishna.s.vasudevan
Yes, the order matters. The first SLG's result feeds into the second SLG, and so on ...

Ping Anoop Sam John and Andrew Purtell as well.

Thanks.

Jerry He not sure whether Andrew Purtell is ok with the change in EnforcingScanLabelGenerator
If EnforcingScanLabelGenerator alone is used, then it will allow whatever the auths passed to it, even if it is NOT authorized for the given user. So this assumes already the check is done by some one else. I am -0 for this.

Hi, Anoop Sam John

What do you think if I keep the original EnforcingScanLabelGenerator as it was, and name the modified version to a different SLG in the stack?
What other ideas do you prefer?

So a new SLG impl, which feed the all the user authorized labels (in case when the Authorizations in Scan is null/empty) and making this 1st in the stack and adding the modified DefaultSLG impl (new name) as 2nd one will make things work.

We will have 3 SLG impls then. The new one which we will creating (as said above) wont be useful as alone (as there is no sanity check for passed in labels)..
Bit complex for the users to play with it. We will need clear documentation on what should be used and when.

Yes, a new SLG. The proposed change to EnforcingScanLabelGenerator would remove its essential feature.

Doesn't have to be complex to configure from the user's perspective, we could provide canned shortcut configuration strings that expand into SLG stacks. Documentation would be good.

I uploaded the patch v4 that addressed comments from Anoop Sam John and Andrew Purtell.
The patch does the following:

1. Renamed the origin DefaultScanLabelGenerator.java to DefinedSetFilterScanLabelGenerator.java
2. New SLG named FeedDefinedSetScanLabelGenerator which just feeds in defined label set if nothing is passed in.
3. No change to EnforcingScanLabelGenerator.
4. Test case.

I will open a separate task to document SLG usage.

Looks great.. Good test..
Don't think javadoc warn is related to this patch. Any way just confirm once Jerry He. Thanks for the nice work.
+1 on patch. Nice comments on the code.
Ping Andrew Purtell. Any comments from you?

Searched thru the Javadoc warnings link.
Does not seem to be related to the patch.

Also

1. Renamed the origin DefaultScanLabelGenerator.java to DefinedSetFilterScanLabelGenerator.java

No change in content except minor change in class level comment.

@apurtell
Is it good to commit now?

Ping Andrew Purtell again

Are you good with the last patch?

Looks pretty good. Minor issue:


191      // If no SLG is specified in conf, by default we'll add two SLGs

192	    // 1. FeedDefinedSetScanLabelGenerator

193	    // 2. DefinedSetFilterScanLabelGenerator

The names of these two SLGs are similar and so have no descriptive power. DefinedSetFilterScanLabelGenerator seems fine, change the name of the other one? Assume I'm +1 after it's clearer what the SLG on the top of the stack does by its name

Thanks for the comment.

Folks, any suggestion for a new name
FeedUserAuthScanLabelGenerator is better?

Sounds good to me.
If there is no objection, I will update the patch tomorrow.
Attached v5 patch that changed the name of the SLG as suggested to FeedUserAuthScanLabelGenerator.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: When no Authorizations passed in Scan , will take user's Auth labels for the Scan and return results accordingly. Prior to this Jira, we were returning only those cells with out any visibility in such a case.
